Award.AbstractNarration:
After the Arab Spring, both Egypt and Tunisia attempted to transition to democracy. Egypt's transition quickly collapsed in a military coup, while Tunisia remains on the path to democratic consolidation. Why? More generally, why do some democratic transitions fall to military coups, while others do not? While existing literature focuses on the opportunity for a coup that is created through economic recessions and political polarization, this dissertation instead highlights the military's will to seize that opportunity. This project examines how the military was treated in the regime prior to democracy will shape whether it gains or loses from democracy, and thus whether it stages a coup or supports the transition. This approach is tested through case studies of Egypt and Tunisia, a survey experiment of military officers, and a statistical analysis of all democratic transitions.

Why do some militaries stage coups against nascent democracies while others do not? This project argues that the military's decision to thwart or accept a democratic transition is shaped by its former autocrat's coup-proofing strategy. Militaries are more likely to obstruct democratization when they had historically been coopted by their autocrats through a share of power or shared identity, and thus lose their privileged positions under democracy. By contrast, militaries should be more supportive of democratization when they had historically been marginalized, fragmented, and counterbalanced by their autocrats, and thus gain from democracy. This project examines this theory through case studies of Egypt and Tunisia, drawing upon nearly 100 interviews and a survey experiment of military officers. It then probes the generalizability of the theory through a cross-national analysis of all democratic transitions between 1783-2016.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation and book project sought to examine why Tunisia's military supported democratization after the Arab Spring, while Egypt's military opposed it. More generally, it sought to understand why some militaries support and others abort democratic transitions. This is an important question, since the vast majority of democratic transitions that break down -- 68% -- do so through military coups. 

The argument put forth is that how militaries behave during democratic transitions is shaped by how they had been treated prior to the transition - under autocracy. Militaries that had been coopted under autocracy by a share of power or shared identity tend to lose those privileges under democracy, sparking a coup. Militaries that instead were neglected, fragmented, and counterbalanced under autocracy tend to gain from democracy, wedding them to the transition. These military legacies from autocracy thus shape the likelihood that a democratic transition succeeds or fails.

To provide empirical evidence of this theory, the dissertation and book project conducted in-depth case studies of Egypt and Tunisia's post-Arab Spring transitions, drawing on over 100 interviews conducted with civilian and military leaders over 15 months in the field. The NSF grant helped to fund the final trip to Tunisia, during which I interviewed the former defense minister, commander of the national guard, presidential spokesman, and several members of parliament.

In addition to these interviews, the project quantitatively tests the theory through two unique surveys of military personnel. The first survey was conducted in 2016 with Tunisia's retired officers association, reaching 72 retired senior military officers. To examine junior officers, as well as to conduct a survey in Egypt, I used the NSF funding to conduct a second survey in August 2018. The survey was conducted online through targeted Facebook advertisements and reached over 200 Tunisian and 2000 Egyptian military personnel, both active-duty and retired. The surveys provide some of the first data on military officers' attitudes toward democracy, and provide strong evidence that how each military had been treated under autocracy shaped what happened to them under democracy, leading them to support or oppose democratization.

The final chapter of the dissertation examines whether the theory generalizes beyond Egypt and Tunisia. It conducts a cross-national statistical analysis of all 232 democratic transitions from 1783-2016. Examining each case, I coded whether prior to the transition the military had been coopted, like in Egypt, or counterbalanced, like in Tunisia. I then traced the effect of these autocratic strategies on the outcome of each democratic transition. What I found was that 66% of democratic transitions featuring a coopted military fell to a military coup, while only 3% of those with counterbalanced militaries did so.

In sum, the dissertation generates a novel theory about when militaries are likely to undermine democratization, highlighting a new structural factor: how militaries had been coup-proofed under autocracy. More generally, the dissertation, thanks to the support of the NSF, has provided a new way to survey hard-to-reach populations like the military: targeted advertisements on Facebook. The substantive and methodological contributions of the dissertation have been disseminated through a number of academic and public forums and have already been cited and adopted by reseachers in the discipline and beyond.
